summary: A detailed video analysis about bicycle saddles, focusing on bike fitting and saddle selection. The analysis covers character descriptions, scene breakdowns, thematic elements, narrative progression, storylines, trimming suggestions, and a Q&A section.

events_list.video_caption: The video opens with a view of a bicycle shop, showcasing various bicycles and accessories on display. The shop's entrance features a black door with a glass panel, and the address "120a" is visible above it. Inside, the shop is well-lit, with bicycles mounted on the walls and shelves filled with bike parts and tools. The scene transitions to a close-up of a bicycle wheel being cleaned with a cloth, accompanied by the text "TUESDAYS*" (Tuesday's) overlaid on the image. A person is then seen crouching and using a red tool on a bicycle wheel, with a brick wall in the background. The focus shifts to a man in a gray sweater and jeans, who is seen interacting with a wooden cabinet in a room with a brick wall and a skeleton model. He retrieves a pair of black shoes from the cabinet and examines them closely. The video then shows a close-up of a hand adjusting a bicycle saddle, followed by the man sitting on a bicycle and pedaling, with a brick wall and a black chair in the background. The video concludes with the man continuing to pedal the bicycle, demonstrating its functionality.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a suspenseful electronic dance music track. Then, a male speaker says "That saddle," followed by another male speaker saying, "perfectly saddle. Stupid saddle." Another male speaker asks, "what are you doing?" to which the second male speaker responds, "mate. Wanna talk about saddles?" The first speaker inquires, "Oh, we're filming a Bike or Tuesdays, alright yeah? Alright. Good." He then continues, "We got a bunch of saddles here, which one is the best for road cycling? Which one is the best for me?" The first male speaker says "This one." Then the second male speaker states, "I'm not riding that," then transitions to "The roll of a saddle."

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing a gray sweater and blue jeans is seated in a wooden chair, surrounded by various bicycle seats on a table in front of him. He appears to be engaged in a discussion, gesturing with his hands as he speaks. The background features a brick wall, a black office chair, and a wooden panel wall, creating a cozy and professional atmosphere. The man then picks up a white anatomical model of a human pelvis and spine, holding it up to the camera to explain its features. He rotates the model, pointing out specific parts and demonstrating its structure. The video captures the man's focused and informative demeanor as he educates the viewer on the anatomy of the pelvis and spine, using the model as a visual aid.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker discussing the role of a bicycle seat in supporting and stabilizing the pelvis, suggesting engaging the "sit bones or ischial pubic rami," sometimes both depending on the "pelvic orientation," explaining whether it is anteriorly or posteriorly rotated. He states this will determine the saddle shape that will work best.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing a gray sweater and blue jeans is seated in a room with a brick wall and a white counter in the background. He is holding a model of a human pelvis and spine, which he uses to explain various aspects of the anatomy. The man gestures with his hands as he talks, pointing to different parts of the model. The scene then transitions to a close-up of two bicycle seats on a table, one of which is blue with the word "TEST" written on it in red letters, and the other is black. The man continues to explain, now holding a black bicycle seat and pointing to its features. The video maintains a professional and educational atmosphere, with the man appearing to be in a medical or educational setting, possibly discussing the anatomy of the pelvis and spine in relation to cycling.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a single male speaker with a conversational tone, discussing the need for a pressure relief channel on a bicycle seat. He emphasizes that not everyone needs one and describes it as the hole cut in the middle intended to "offload soft tissue," mentioning studies about "sterility," "erectile dysfunction," and "nastier things."

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing a gray sweater and blue jeans is seated in a chair, holding a black object in his right hand and a white model of a human pelvis in his left hand. He appears to be explaining or demonstrating something related to the object and the model. The man is gesturing with his hands, pointing to different parts of the model and the object, indicating a detailed discussion or presentation. The background features a brick wall, a desk with a computer monitor, and a black office chair, suggesting an office or educational setting. The man's facial expressions and hand movements convey a sense of engagement and focus on the topic at hand.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker, in an informative and slightly conversational tone, discussing how certain types of saddles might be uncomfortable if the rider has pelvic rotation. He continues, mentioning that riders might sit off to one side due to various reasons like insufficient foot support, excessive saddle height, or reach, or even to alleviate soft tissue pressure. The speaker notes that riders may sit askew to make themselves comfortable.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing a gray sweater and blue jeans is seated in a chair, holding a model of a human pelvis and spine. He appears to be explaining or demonstrating something related to the model, gesturing with his hands and occasionally pointing to specific parts of the model. The background features a brick wall, a black office chair, and a desk with a computer monitor. The man then picks up a blue bicycle saddle with the text "fi'zi:k" and "TEST" written on it, comparing it to the model of the pelvis and spine, possibly discussing the relationship between the two. The video includes close-up shots of the bicycle saddle, highlighting its design and features. The man continues to hold both the model and the saddle, emphasizing certain aspects of the model while holding the saddle in his other hand. The setting remains consistent throughout the video, with the man seated in the same chair, and the background elements unchanged. The video concludes with the man still holding the model and the saddle, continuing his explanation or demonstration.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a single male speaker discussing bike saddles. He describes the types of saddles that riders tend to purchase, mentioning Pro Griffon and Specialized Toupe as examples, and notes his lack of success with flatter saddles. He explains the pelvic alignment and spinal flexion issues associated with the flatter saddles, and ultimately concludes it is not good. The audio clip concludes with the speaker abruptly saying “you.”

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing a gray sweater and blue jeans is seated in a chair, holding a model of a human spine on a blue tray. He appears to be explaining or discussing something related to the spine model, using hand gestures to emphasize his points. The setting is an indoor room with a brick wall and wooden paneling in the background, along with a black office chair and a desk with a computer monitor. The man's facial expressions and body language suggest he is engaged in a detailed explanation or presentation. As the video progresses, the man continues to gesture and talk, occasionally pointing to the spine model to highlight specific features. He then shifts his focus to a black object, possibly a shoe, which he picks up and examines, continuing his discussion with hand movements. The overall atmosphere is educational and informative, with the man actively engaging with the audience through his gestures and explanations.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker discussing the prevalence of a saddle brand's compensation system, humorously avoiding naming the developer. He then clarifies that viewers likely want to find the best saddle due to discomfort, raising the question of why they are considering a new saddle. The speaker believes saddle discomfort mostly stems from bad positions, not saddles. He adds that saddle sores result from asymmetrical bike interactions, which he believes results in saddle sores primarily on one side. He concludes, noting that bilateral sores point to extremely poor positioning.

events_list.audio_caption: The clip features one male speaker discussing saddles, specifically mentioning the "Pro Griffon" and saddles from Specialized and Bontrager. He emphasizes the importance of features like flatness and a pressure relief channel. He mentions that most of his customers end up using this saddle. In the background, we hear music playing with a somewhat somber tone.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man is seated in a modern office environment, wearing a gray sweater and blue jeans. He is holding a black object, which appears to be a gaming controller, and is engaged in a conversation or presentation, gesturing with his hands to emphasize his points. events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a male speaker discussing saddle fitting, noting that the "152 width tends to be a little bit too wide." He then challenges the common saddle fitting systems, explaining that they are often "driven by measuring sit bone width" but, in his experience, "sit bone width doesn't really have that much now saying in saddle selection." The speaker's tone is informative and slightly critical.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man is seated in a modern office setting, wearing a gray sweater and blue jeans. He is engaged in a conversation, gesturing with his hands to emphasize his points. The office features a brick wall, a desk with a computer monitor, and a black office chair. The man holds a tablet, which he uses to interact with the audience or to reference information during his discussion. The atmosphere is professional and focused, with the man appearing to be in a relaxed yet attentive posture. The lighting is bright, highlighting the details of the room and the man's expressions. The video captures the man's dynamic interaction, showcasing his engagement and the use of technology in his communication.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker discussing the "noseless saddle" concept. He states it is a "very, very popular concept" and describes a design philosophy he has "increasing difficulty with." The speaker elaborates on issues stemming from "the excessive width of the rear portion of the saddle." He states this "tends to drive riders to the nose of the saddle," which is "a problem because the nose doesn't exist."

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man is seated in a modern office setting, wearing a gray sweater and blue jeans. He is holding a black object, which appears to be a gaming controller, and is deeply engaged in a conversation, gesturing with his hands as he speaks. The office features a brick wall, a wooden desk, and a black office chair, creating a professional yet casual atmosphere. The man's facial expressions and body language suggest he is explaining or discussing something with enthusiasm. The lighting is bright, highlighting the details of the room and the man's attire. The video captures a moment of interaction, possibly during a break or a casual meeting, where the man is animatedly sharing his thoughts or experiences related to the object in his hands.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a single male speaker explaining something marketed as enabling a more aerodynamic position. He describes the ability to get a "nose of the saddle" further forward and mentioning UCI's 5 centimeter rule. He further explains that an "average Joe" shouldn't try to push the saddle forward because it only puts more strain on the knee.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man is seated in a chair, wearing a gray sweater and blue jeans, holding a black object in his hands. He appears to be examining or demonstrating the object, which seems to be a piece of equipment or a gadget. The man is in an indoor setting, possibly an office or a studio, with a brick wall and wooden paneling in the background. There is a desk with a computer monitor and other office items visible behind him. The man's facial expressions and gestures suggest he is explaining or discussing the object, occasionally looking at it closely and pointing out specific features. The atmosphere is casual and focused on the demonstration or explanation of the object.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker discussing bike saddles, mentioning the "Pro Stealth", "Specialized Power", and "Prologo Dimension". He expresses frustration with "noseless saddles" and their applicability for everyday cyclists. He argues that professional cyclists' use of such products shouldn't be the main factor for consumer choices, as they are often sponsored to use certain products. The speaker then states he's having increasing difficulty with noseless saddles and has "a hell of a lot more success" with traditional flat saddles.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing a gray sweater and blue jeans is seated in a chair, holding a black object that appears to be a prosthetic limb. He is in a room with a brick wall and a white counter, with a black office chair and a red cabinet visible in the background. The man is demonstrating the prosthetic limb, showing its different parts and how it can be adjusted. He is wearing a watch on his left wrist and has a beard. The man is explaining the features of the prosthetic limb, pointing out its various components and how they fit together. He is also holding a white object, which seems to be a model of a human pelvis, and is using it to illustrate how the prosthetic limb attaches to the body. The man appears to be engaged in a detailed discussion, possibly for educational or promotional purposes, as he gestures with his hands and looks directly at the camera. The lighting in the room is bright, and the overall atmosphere is professional and informative.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a male speaker discussing bicycle saddles, specifically noting that he sells them to the right person on the right bike, mentioning an "ISM PM 3.1" saddle. He specifies that this is a time trial and triathlon saddle designed to "load a different part of the pelvis," further forward, and meant for riding in "a more anteriorly rotated" position. He speaks in an informative and descriptive tone.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man is seated in a chair, wearing a gray sweater and blue jeans, holding a black object in his hands. He appears to be examining the object closely, turning it around and inspecting it from different angles. The man is in a room with a brick wall and wooden paneling, and there is a white plate with a model of a human spine on his lap. The man seems to be explaining or discussing the object, gesturing with his hands and occasionally looking at the camera. The atmosphere is casual and focused, with the man's attention primarily on the object in his hands. The video captures the man's actions and expressions as he interacts with the object, providing a detailed view of his examination and discussion.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a man speaking with a slightly argumentative tone, expressing his opinion on a specific saddle type, stating that it "doesn't really have any place on a road bike." He elaborates on its perceived inadequacy in supporting the pelvis, suggesting it's often a last resort for riders experiencing genital numbness due to improper bike positioning. He emphasizes that if numbness occurs with such a saddle, it indicates a problem beyond the saddle itself and recommends a professional position assessment. He concludes by stating that this type of saddle should only be for triathlon and time trials.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man is seated in a modern office setting, wearing a gray sweater and blue jeans, with a watch on his left wrist. He is engaged in a conversation, using expressive hand gestures to emphasize his points. The office features a brick wall, wooden paneling, and a black office chair in the background. A microphone with a blue cover is visible on the table in front of him, indicating a possible recording or interview session. The man appears to be explaining something with enthusiasm, as his gestures become more animated. The video concludes with a black screen displaying a message of gratitude to sponsors, including logos of brands like ATTACUS, Wilier, MET, DENERVIT, and skin grows back, along with a request to subscribe. The text reads, "PLEASE SUBSCRIBE THANKS TO THE FOLLOWING BRANDS FOR SPONSORING ME & HELPING THE CHANNEL THRIVE."
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker describing the information about saddles as "just the tip of the iceberg," suggesting the need for further discussion. He then invites the listeners to ask questions in the comments about saddle fitting, promising to answer them. A second speaker, also male, adds, "And subscribe for more," repeating the same phrase afterward to end the clip.
